title: Nonverbal Learning Disorder (NVLD)
author: Alyson Powell Key

sections.heading: What Is Nonverbal Learning Disorder?
content: Nonverbal learning disorder (NVLD), also called nonverbal learning disability (NLD), is a condition that makes it hard to process visual, spatial, and other types of information.
Children with NVLD often have strong verbal skills. They’re usually good at reading (though they may have trouble comprehending what they read) and spelling, too.
But they struggle with nonverbal skills, such as:

While NVLD is not an official diagnosis or disorder, some experts are pushing to include it in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM). That’s what the American Psychiatric Association uses to define and classify mental disorders.
This will help people with NVLD get better care and other resources, and scientists are more likely to get funding to study the condition.
A child with NVLD may show weaknesses in one or more of five areas:

Visual and spatial awareness. Many kids with NVLD have issues understanding visual imagery and how things fit together in space, which makes it hard for them to know where things are in relation to each other.

sections.heading: Nonverbal learning disorder vs. autism
content: Higher-order comprehension. This skill involves spotting a main idea, the supporting details, and how ideas connect. It affects how well kids understand what they read and write and how they tell stories.
Social communication. Kids with NVLD may have trouble understanding emotions through facial expressions and body language. They often miss social cues that other kids notice easily.
Math concepts. Older kids may struggle to solve advanced math problems that require them to recognize concepts and patterns.
Executive functions. These are the skills we use to organize our thoughts, make plans, take action, and solve problems.
The symptoms of NVLD can look similar to other conditions, including ADHD and autism. Doctors sometimes confuse these disorders, especially since many kids with NVLD also have autism and ADHD.

Both autism and NVLD cause problems with social skills and communication. There are key differences, though. Unlike children with autism, kids with NVLD don’t have trouble with verbal communication or repetitive behaviors.

sections.heading: Nonverbal Learning Disorder Causes
content: Researchers think dysfunction in the right hemisphere of the brain in what’s called “ white matter ” may lead to NVLD. Changes in this area of the brain can affect the transmission of neurological signals, triggering NVLD symptoms.

sections.heading: Nonverbal learning disorder in adults
content: Symptoms can range from mild to severe, and your child may only show a few signs of NVLD. One study of more than 100 students with the disorder found that the largest group showed signs from all five areas, while the second largest group only had two.
While NVLD usually affects children, adults can also have it. Many adults with NVLD never received a diagnosis or treatment when they were kids.

As an adult with this learning disability, you may have social or romantic problems along with issues at work and in your daily life. NVLD symptoms in adults can look similar to those in kids and include problems with:
Adults with the condition might also have trouble:
bullets: Asking too many questions or questions that are out of place
Reading body language, tone, facial expressions, and social cues
Following directions with more than one step
Adjusting to a change in routine
Trying new things or going somewhere new
Processing visual information such as maps and charts
A sense of direction (gets lost easily)

sections.heading: Nonverbal Learning Disorder Treatment
content: After testing, your child’s psychologist will share a report outlining their findings and therapies to help manage NVLD. There are different ways to help your child improve their skills and manage challenges with NVLD, including:
Social skills groups. Your child will learn to greet people, join conversations, spot and respond to teasing, and other social skills.

sections.heading: Occupational therapy .
content: This type of therapy improves coordination and fine motor skills and helps your child adjust to being outdoors.
Cognitive therapy. NVLD can trigger anxiety and other mental health issues, which cognitive therapy addresses.

There are no medications that directly treat NVLD. But if your child has symptoms of the disorder, such as anxiety, mood swings , or trouble focusing, your child's doctor may prescribe an antidepressant , mood stabilizer, or ADHD medication .

sections.heading: Caretaking for a Child With Nonverbal Learning Disorder
content: Parents and caretakers of kids with NVLD often encounter issues like a lack of flexibility, meltdowns, and social awkwardness. Here are some ways to manage these challenges:
Inflexibility. Children with NVLD like structure and get frustrated when things don’t go as expected. They often struggle to adapt to change, appearing stubborn or wanting to argue.
Tips:

Meltdowns. Kids with NVLD can be easily overwhelmed, especially when routines change, even in fun situations. Understanding what triggers your child’s frustration , like hunger or tiredness, can help avoid meltdowns.
bullets: Show empathy while explaining necessary changes.
Set clear rules for common problem situations.

sections.heading: Tips:
content: Social awkwardness. It’s common for children with NVLD to miss nonverbal cues, making it hard for them to understand social interactions. They might misread others' behavior or be unaware of how their own actions affect others. This can make them vulnerable to bullying or misunderstandings.
Tips:

Other challenges. Kids with NVLD often take things literally, missing jokes or figures of speech. They may also have poor spatial awareness, which makes understanding personal space difficult and complicates playing sports.
Tips:
bullets: Prepare your child by previewing situations.
Step in early with a distraction or calming break when frustration starts.
Have a quick exit plan if things escalate.
Explain NVLD to people who often interact with your child, such as family members.
Don’t blame your child for things they don’t understand. Instead, talk through strategies and help them process social situations.
Be direct when communicating, and be patient when they misunderstand.
Use visual aids, like a hula hoop, to explain personal space.
Encourage activities like swimming or martial arts that don’t rely on spatial awareness.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Nonverbal learning disorder (NVLD) affects how you process visual and nonverbal information, making it hard to understand social cues, visual-spatial relationships, and abstract concepts. While diagnostic manuals don’t officially recognize NVLD, experts believe it stems from dysfunction in the brain’s right hemisphere.

Treatment may include social skills training, occupational therapy, and cognitive therapy to help manage anxiety and improve coordination. Caregivers and educators can also support children with NVLD by providing clear instructions, encouraging social interaction, and using visual aids to teach spatial awareness.

sections.heading: Nonverbal Learning Disorder FAQs
content: Here are some frequently asked questions about nonverbal learning disorder.
NVLD shares similarities with autism, but key differences include the absence of verbal communication problems or repetitive behaviors in children with NVLD.
People with nonverbal learning disability have challenges with processing visual and nonverbal communication.

While doctors often diagnose NVLD in children, adults can also face challenges in social and work settings, especially when it comes to reading nonverbal cues and managing tasks that require organization or visual-spatial skills.

sections.heading: Do people with NVLD have sensory issues?
content: Since NVLD isn’t included in the DSM, the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) doesn’t cover the disorder. But children can still get classroom accommodations under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act.
Ask your child’s neurologist if they’re willing to write a report outlining the disorder and ask for accommodations like allowing your child to take a different course.
NVLD may affect your sense of hearing, taste, smell, or touch.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Nonverbal learning disorder (NVLD) affects how you process visual and nonverbal information, making it hard to understand social cues, visual-spatial relationships, and abstract concepts. While diagnostic manuals don’t officially recognize NVLD, experts believe it stems from dysfunction in the brain’s right hemisphere.

Treatment may include social skills training, occupational therapy, and cognitive therapy to help manage anxiety and improve coordination. Caregivers and educators can also support children with NVLD by providing clear instructions, encouraging social interaction, and using visual aids to teach spatial awareness.

meta_description: Nonverbal Learning Disorder (NVLD) is a neurological condition affecting spatial awareness, motor skills, and social cues, with strengths in verbal skills but challenges in nonverbal communication.
